conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the balls and the rod when ball A is at the highest point.
Ball A is at the highest point and exerts no force on the rod.
The centripetal force required to keep ball A in circular motion is provided entirely by gravity.
Centripetal force formula: \( F_c = \frac{mv^2}{r} \), where \( v \) is velocity and \( r \) is radius.
Set up the equation for ball A: \( mg = \frac{mv^2}{L} \).
Ball B is located at a distance \( 2L \) from the axis of rotation.
The rod is rigid, so the angular velocity \( \omega \) is the same for both balls.
The linear velocity \( v_B \) of ball B is given by \( v_B = \omega \cdot 2L \).
Calculate the centripetal force on ball B: \( F_{cB} = \frac{mv_B^2}{2L} = \frac{2mv^2}{L} \).
Substitute \( v^2 = gL \) into the equation for ball B: \( F_{cB} = 2mg \).
Determine the net force on ball B: \( F_B = F_{cB} - mg = mg \).
The force exerted by ball B on the rod when ball A is at the highest point is \( mg \).
